I suppose it's not the worst party game I've played, so I can't bash it too much. You get a word and everyone secretly comes up with their "fake" definition. Then all players vote on which one they think is the real definition, and you score points for players choosing your definition. It's better than getting into a political argument with family members, I suppose.

Oh, Balderdash...

Balderdash begins with the beginning half of a fact, and the players write down fake out answers. The goal then becomes to find the real one.

Balderdash in this era suffers because there are better games on the market that do what it tries to do.

Sounds fishy by Big Potato games does away with the paper aspect, but only has one guesser at a time, for example

Fibbage by Jackbox games does this game concept digitally, and is quite well-liked being one of their flagship games.

The game has a brilliant concept, but has been innovated on.

You've got some more modern options, and I would suggest those over Balderdash, but Balderdash can still certainly be fun by itself.
Interesting party game. Have to fake definitions of words.
Used to play this with my family all the time growing up. It is still a decent game, but only you might as well just play a JackBox Party Pack on a video game console of choice.

I have fonder memories of this game when I was younger, playing at Grandma's house, before I realized how easy it is to tell the real definition from the fakes.
Funny party game, but it requires a crowd of like-minded people who will approach it in the same way. I think it was great when it came out, but I think it's been surpassed.

Balderdash aka Fictionary aka Lexicon aka The Dictionary Game.

Play with a large, preferably unabridged dictionary (or Internet access), as well as a writing implement and index cards (or identical pieces of paper) for each player.

Play online at dictgame.azurewebsites.net, or with the help of an LLM, or one of the many word lists available online:
[list]
[*]Balderdash words lists
[*]Fictionary words lists
[*]Lexicon words lists
[*]The Dictionary Game words lists
[/list]

How we score:
[list]
[*]Earn 1 point for every vote on your answer. (Note: You cannot vote for your own answer.)
[*]Earn 2 points if you vote for the correct answer.
[*]Earn 3 points if you write an answer that is very close to the correct answer.
[*]If no one votes for or guesses the correct answer, the leader earns 3 points.
[*]The winner is the first player to reach 15 points.
[/list]

Our favorite categories:
[list=1]
[*]Laughable Laws: Guess the reasoning or context behind absurd or outdated laws.
[*]Famous for What?: Identify what a lesser-known person is remembered for.
[*]Plot Twist: Create a story for an obscure or foreign film based on its title.
[*]On This Day: Imagine or recall a significant event from a specific historical date.
[*]Define That Word: Guess the meaning of an unusual or rare word.
[*]Decode the Acronym: Invent a plausible (or hilarious) expansion for a given acronym.
[*]Phrase Craze: Interpret the meaning of an idiom, saying, or slang term.
[*]What's This Thing?: Guess the purpose or origin of a peculiar object or invention.
[*]Mystery Dish: Deduce the dish or beverage from a list of unusual ingredients or steps.
[/list]

Played this for the first time recently. It's a classic for a reason. Many of these "mini games" have been made into Jackbox Party games, but Balderdash still does it better than all of them. Gives you plenty of opportunity to be clever and creative.

The first among it's kind for me. Classic and incredible replayability, but less often brought out than others due simply to the fact it requires a lot of on the spot improvising and creativity than some simply don't find fun.

I love this game and would always happily play it at lighter 'non gamer' nights, but it is less loved by some of my friends.

With the right crowd, Balderdash is such a fun party game. It doesn't always hit the mark though as it relies on people being able to read each other's handwriting without giving the game away and it has limited shelf life as the real answers can be learned by players with good memories (much like a quiz game). It also relies on people being able to think creatively, which isn't everyone's cup of tea when playing a game, so can be off-putting for some.
Who doesn’t like a chance to embellish the truth. Fun game of deception.
